div.div:
Waterloo Staff
is a Person of Color

Graduation Rate
Highest in District History

Career Programs
Four More Coming This Fall

p.span: Starting Wednesday, April 15, Waterloo Schools is launching the next phase of continuous learning as the Covid-19 Shutdown continues through April 30.

Please see info below for three levels: elementary school, middle school and high school:
Click here for printable versions for PreK-5.
-Two weeks of lessons in a paper packet (math, literacy) will be provided to
preschool and K-1 students every two weeks.
-All PK-1 students will be expected to complete the packet. Teachers will contact students and parents to provide support with the packet work.
-Students in grades PK-1 will be expected to engage in learning approximately 1-1½ hours each weekday.
-Students will be expected to complete assigned work and communicate with teachers about their work.
, the PK-1 packets will be available at the Grab and Go meal sites on
or mailed upon request. Here is the schedule:
Cunningham, Kingsley, and Orange
Kittrell, Highland
11am-12pm
Becker and Lou Henry
Irving, Lincoln, Poyner
9am-12pm
Education Service Center, 1516 Washington St. (site for Lowell)

-Beginning this Friday and every Friday after, teachers in grades 2-5 will post four lessons/activities per week on Google Classroom. That work is due the following Friday by 5pm and will be done in Google Classroom.
p.b: -For students who don’t have access to the internet,
p.span: two weeks of lessons in a paper packet will be provided to 2-5 grade students every two weeks.
-Students have the necessary link and password for Google Classroom but should talk with their teacher if they have any trouble logging on.
-Teachers will review work online or reach out to students doing paper packets. Please let your teacher know if you are needing to do the work through a packet.
-Students will be expected to complete assigned work and communicate with teachers about their work.

-Students will be expected to participate in Google Classroom lessons and online meetings with teachers as they are able, or to communicate via phone calls. Again, work with your teacher to express your preferred method.
-Students in grades 2-5 are expected to engage in learning approximately 1½ to 2 hours. Of this time, at least 30 minutes each day should be reading or being read to.
, a limited number of hard copies of all materials will be available
only
for families without access at the Grab and Go meal sites on
or mailed upon request.

p.b: Remember: 2-5 GRADE PAPER PACKETS ARE ONLY FOR FAMILIES
WHO DO NOT HAVE ACCESS TO THE INTERNET

p.span: -Assignments for all classes will be posted on Friday afternoons on Google Classroom and will be expected to be completed by the following Friday.

-Students will connect online with teachers through Google Classroom to get assignments. Students have the necessary link and password for Google Classroom but should reach out to their teacher if they have any trouble logging in.
-Students will be expected to complete assigned work and communicate with teachers about their work.
-Students will be expected to participate in Google Classroom lessons and online meetings with teachers as they are able.
-Students will be expected to engage in learning approximately three hours each weekday.
-Teachers will review work online or reach out to students doing paper packets. Please let your teacher know if you are needing to do the work through a packet.

p.b: Middle School students WITH NO INTERNET ACCESS who need hard copies:
p.span: , a limited number of hard copies of all materials will be available
only
for families without access at the Grab and Go meal sites on
or mailed upon request. Here is the schedule:
Cunningham, Kingsley, and Orange
Kittrell, Highland
11am-12pm
Becker and Lou Henry
Irving, Lincoln, Poyner
9am-12pm
Education Service Center, 1516 Washington St. (site for Lowell)
Waterloo Schools High School Students will:
-Check and respond to email twice daily.
-Connect with and engage in virtual classroom activities daily.
-Connect with each of your teachers at least twice a week (once for class and once as a check and connect).
-Complete any formative assessment (quiz, exit ticket, collaborative project) given by your teacher.
-Connect with your counselor or administrator with any issues you are having connecting to classes.
-Reach out to your counselor or administrator with any social or emotional needs you may have.
-Lessons will be posted using the following schedule:

div.p:
Monday: Literacy
Tuesday: Math
Wednesday: Social Studies
Thursday: Science
Friday: World Languages

p.b: High School students WITH NO INTERNET ACCESS who need hard copies:

p.span: , a limited number of hard copies of all materials will be available
only
for families without access at the Grab and Go meal sites on
or mailed upon request. Here is the schedule:
Cunningham, Kingsley, and Orange
Kittrell, Highland
11am-12pm
Becker and Lou Henry
Irving, Lincoln, Poyner
9am-12pm
Education Service Center, 1516 Washington St. (site for Lowell)

p.b: Questions? Contact your child’s teacher by email or call your child’s school office and leave a message for their teacher.

p.span: Google Classroom is your child’s digital link for learning. It’s a safe and moderated place for them to communicate with their teacher and classmates, get assignments, take quizzes and receive feedback on their school work!
Video with more info:
Info slides (

article.class: post-14629 post type-post status-publish format-standard category-covid-19 entry

div.p: Thank you for your patience as we continue finalizing continuous learning plans for our students, staff & families heading into the extended COVID-19 shutdown through Thursday, April 30. As you may have heard, this week Waterloo Schools will begin implementation of the Voluntary Enrichment Plan as specified by Governor Reynolds. These days will count toward instruction and will not need to be made up.

As we gear up for the official launch on Wednesday, our staff will use Monday and Tuesday, (April 13 & April 14) to collaborate on the plan, finalize preparations, and complete professional development for our extended continuous learning to begin for students on Wednesday, April 15.

Additional details for families will be sent on Tuesday to prepare for the Wednesday launch. Please call 433-2020 with general questions about the school shutdown or call your child’s school and leave a message, as staff are returning calls.

article.class: post-14623 post type-post status-publish format-standard category-covid-19 entry

div.p: NEW THIS WEEK: There will be NO curbside or drop-off meal service this Friday, April 10. Thursday pick-up locations will provide meals for Thursday, Friday & weekend backpacks while supplies last.
*NEW SCHEDULE* CURBSIDE FREE MEAL PICK-UP
STARTING MONDAY, APRIL 13
MONDAY, WEDNESDAY, FRIDAY ONLY

Starting Monday, April 13 we are changing our free meal pick-up to Mondays, Wednesdays, & Fridays. On Mondays, meals for Monday & Tuesday will be handed out. On Wednesday, meals for Wednesday & Thursday will be handed out. On Friday, meals for Friday & backpacks of food for the weekend will be handed out while supplies last.

Meals will be still delivered to Cedar Crest & Lantern Square apartments where families can walk out and pick them up from 10-11am now on Monday, Wednesday & Friday. These remote sites do not have the capacity to offer the backpacks.
Cedar Crest: Pick up in the common area behind the apartments on Columbia St. and West Dale St.
Lantern Square: Pick up near the front where residents enter for the pool.
Curbside Meal Pick-Up
Parents/Guardians drive or walk-up to pick one up. Here is the Mon./Wed./Fri. schedule:
9-10am: Cunningham, Kingsley, and Orange
10-11am: Kittrell, Highland
11am-12pm: Becker and Lou Henry
12-1pm: Irving, Lincoln, Poyner
9am-12pm: Education Service Center, 1516 Washington St. (site for Lowell) Feminine hygiene products available for families at this location.

article.class: post-14619 post type-post status-publish format-standard category-covid-19 entry

div.p: Tomorrow (Wed., April 8), we are offering a very limited Chromebook pick-up option for elementary students in grades 2-5 and students in Expo alternative programs; however, this is ONLY for students who DO NOT have access to a device, including access to a sibling’s district-issued Chromebook. We want to support online learning from home, but we have a limited number of devices. If you do not have access to a Chromebook for your child to continue his or her online learning, you may pick one up at the nearest elementary school from 4-6pm on Wednesday, April 8.

-Drive or walk up to pick up a Chromebook.
-Each family will be assigned ONE Chromebook for all children in the household to share.
-Each family must sign a loan agreement form at time of pick-up.
-These Chromebooks will be on loan from Waterloo Schools. Parents will be responsible for
returning Chromebooks at the end of the school year in the same condition as
received.
More information will be coming soon for families that still don’t have internet access at home.
Chromebook Pick-up at the following elementary schools Wed., April 8 from 4-6pm:

article.class: post-14614 post type-post status-publish format-standard category-covid-19 entry

div.p: Call the District Shutdown Hotline 319-433-2020 for general questions regarding the district shutdown.

div.p: Thank you for your patience as we continue finalizing continuous learning plans for our students, staff & families heading into the extended COVID-19 shutdown through Thursday, April 30. As you may have heard, this week Waterloo Schools will begin implementation of the Voluntary Enrichment Plan as specified by Governor Reynolds. These days will count toward […]
The Waterloo Community School District is committed to ensuring that the content on its website is accessible to everyone, including those with disabilities and users of assistive technology.
If you are having problems accessing parts of the site, please contact Katrina Hemann at [email protected]. Follow this link for more information.

It is the policy of the Waterloo Community School District not to illegally discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, disability, religion, creed, age (for employment), marital status (for programs), sexual orientation, gender identity, and socioeconomic status (for programs) in its educational programs and its employment practices. There is a grievance procedure for processing complaints of discrimination. If you have questions or a grievance related to this policy please contact:

District Equity/Affirmative Action Officer
Kingsley Botchway II, Chief Officer of Human Resources/Equity
1516 Washington Street
319-433-1800
[email protected].
